Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Closed-Loop Methodology for Investigating Trust, Culture, and Information Sharing in Global Supply Chains

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program grant will combine mathematical modeling and human-subject experiments to study the impacts of trust and culture on information sharing in global supply chains. Supply chains today transcend country borders and therefore, can be difficult to manage. To ensure economic and market efficiency, it is critical that truthful information sharing occurs between business partners within a supply chain. This grant supports an integrative research and education plan to advance the field of operations management (OM) by incorporating two new aspects that have not previously been considered: (i) behavioral motives of the human decision makers involved in the information sharing process and (ii) cultural heterogeneity in a global supply chain. The research will lead to the design of new supply chain processes that incorporate behavioral and cultural factors to improve information sharing in global supply chains. The multidisciplinary approach will facilitate scientific collaboration across different fields including OM, economics, psychology, and sociology. It will broaden the participation of undergraduates, females, and underrepresented minorities in research in the STEM domain. The unique cross-cultural focus will enable and stimulate international collaboration in research and education.

This award will transform the Operations Management (OM) discipline by developing a scientific methodology to incorporate important insights from psychology and sociology into OM theories and applications. The canonical OM research in information sharing is theoretical in nature and has mainly focused on pecuniary incentives. However, OM systems are managed by humans who are often subject to nonpecuniary incentives that include behavioral and cultural factors. Thus, systems designed without considering these latent factors are prone to failures. This grant fills this gap and strengthens the theoretical and practical values of OM research. The research agenda contains three parts. First, the supply chain information sharing scenario will be mathematically modeled and analyzed based on canonical economic theories. Second, theoretical predictions obtained in part one will guide the scientific design of human-subject experiments both in the lab and in the field to systematically study the impacts of trust and culture on supply chain information sharing. Third, based on empirical insights from the experiments, new theories on strategic information sharing will be developed to capture the elements of trust and culture. This methodology pioneers a closed-loop framework in OM research in which theories inform the design of behavioral experiments, and experimental results in turn lead to enhanced theories that better predict human behavior and improve management prescriptions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) grant combines mathematical modeling and empirical investigation of human behaviors to study the impacts of trust, culture, and information transparency on strategic decisions in global supply chains. Supply chains today transcend country borders and therefore, can be difficult to manage. To ensure economic and market efficiency, it is critical that truthful information sharing occurs between business partners within a supply chain. Furthermore, as global supply chains exert tremendous influence on people's lives, proper behaviors of supply chain stakeholders must be enacted to ensure the environmental and social responsibility of related supply chain activities. This grant supports an integrative research and education plan to advance the field of operations management (OM) by making a number of theoretical and practical contributions with regard to intellectual merit and broader impacts.

Intellectual Merit: (i) We empirically establish and theoretically model the role of trust in strategic supply chain information sharing, which has never been studied in the long history of the OM literature. The research both highlights the presence of trust as a general phenomenon (even among high-ranking executives who are highly conscious of financial goals) and deepens our understanding of when, how, and why trust impacts critical business decisions in different exchange environments. The resulting body of knowledge helps to inform organizations on how to cultivate trust within and across organizational boundaries. The continuing effort to develop a more general model of trust will offer deeper behavioral insights on the evolution of trust in business interactions. (ii) We integrate cross-disciplinary methods to expand the boundaries of research on trust in information sharing and contribute to advancing the general knowledge of trust. The grant has facilitated scientific collaboration across different fields including OM, economics, psychology, and sociology. (iii) We establish a body of knowledge that deepens our understanding of when, how, and why different facets of supply chain transparency impact the behaviors of different stakeholders in global supply chains, as well as how information transparency can be designed to motivate positive behaviors especially associated with environmental and social responsibility. While a large number of consumer studies examine what could motivate the consumption of responsibly-made products, research examining when consumers value transparency and how they change behavior due to transparency is nascent. We address this gap and prescribe practically relevant insights about how to establish responsible practices in global supply chains under realistic constraints. (iv) The research pioneers a closed-loop methodology in OM research, in which current theories inform the design of behavioral studies, and empirical results in turn lead to enhanced theories that better predict human behavior as well as improve management prescriptions.

Broader Impacts: The grant has supported the thesis research of six graduate students (four females) and led to six publications and working papers, the majority of which are published or being reviewed at top journals in the operations management field. The grant also supported the development of a new graduate course offered at MIT on behavioral decision theories and applications. The research has led to the development of a supply chain information sharing simulation game (the Forecast Sharing Game) that is currently being adopted by over 80 professors across 50 universities in their operations management courses at the undergraduate, graduate, and executive education levels. In addition, it has led to the development of a teaching module that discusses the role of supply chain transparency in promoting environmental and social responsibility in global supply chains that involve underprivileged populations. The module has been taught by the PI and collaborators in undergraduate, graduate, and executive education courses and has been well received. The PI organized the 2017 Annual Behavioral Operations Workshop at MIT Sloan in which researchers and practitioners came together to share and learn from each other state-of-the-art research outcomes, methodologies, and management techniques that concern the interface between operations and human behavior.
